709426f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Broadway
709426f-a.text:
Sixth Ayenue and Broadway, north from W. 33rd Street,
showing the "gl" tracks upon the numerical Avenue. To the
right is the diagonal Broadway. 34th Street is where the
Broadway Tabernacle appears. The distinctive Herald Build.
ing is north of 35th Street, separating Proadway (left)
from 6th Avenue. At the left is the southbound platform
obstruucttnng the sign thut identifies Jim Corbett's Saloon.
The latter was a world's heavyweight boxlng champion.
1899
Gift of Urbrock Collection

720394f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 6th Avenue
720394f-a.text:
Broadway and the west side of Sixth Avenue, north from 34th
Street. The centre building, fronting on Broadway and Sixth Ave
was formerly the Seventy-First Regiment Armory, and is now the
New York Herald Building. Later, in 1928, it will be cut in hal
the narrower, southern half will remain, and in 1936 will house
Rogers Peet Company. The 35th Street half, however, will be dem
and replaced by the 24-story Herald Scuare Building.
In the background is the recently built Times Building, whic
caused the name of Longacre Square to be changed to Times Square
About 1905.
MAY BE PEPRODUCED.  e) W G 3

717396f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 33rd Street
717396f.text:
Broadway, north from 3Srd Street, showing also Sixth Avenue,
west side, from 3 'rd to 3oth Streets. Sak's 34th Street store is
in the left foreground with Macy's department store above it. In
the center is the Herald Building. In 1928 it wil be cut in
half, and the northern, or rear portion demolished, with the
Herald Square nuilding ririnr in its site.
In the center backaround is the 8otel Normsndie, and in
slightly left-center backgfound is the Metropolitan Opera Pouse.
Dominating the skyline is the new building of the New Iork
imes.
Ewing Galloway  1909

717397f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 33rd Street
717397f-a.text:
Saks - 34th Street, a large department store, Broadway,
west side, from 34th to 33rd Streets.
About 1921.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

720392f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 6th Avenue
720392f-a.text:
At the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Ave., at West 34th Street.
On the left is Broadway, north from and including West 34th Street. Also
shown is Sixth Ave., (Sixth Ave., Rlevated) north from, but not including
34th Street. Rogers Peet Building is shown on West 35th Street, north
side, from Broadway to Sixth Ave. Macy's Deot., Store is barely discern-
able on Broadway. (Building with clock) The N. Y. Times Building and the
Astor Hotel are shown in the background, at the head of Broadway.
February 7, 1927.
0ea; tGGG E i
New york Sdison Company.

720145f-a.title: Manhattan: 33rd Street (West) - Broadway
720145f-a.text:
Greeley Square, a triangular plot at the convergance of Sirth Ave.,
and Broadway, at West 33rd Street. Across the square appears Broadway at
the S.E. corner of West 33rd Street. This is under the care of the Dept.
of Parks.
April 26, 1934.

709427f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 33rd Street (West)
709427f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at a. 33rd Street, showing the northbound
platform of the cith Avenue "El" outlined against the Hotel
McAlpin. Note at the left the approaching soutbound train.
This one of the last to run over these tracks as April of
this year will see the complete demolition of this line.
March 1939
Wm. Herries

709432f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Broadway
709432f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from West 34th Street, show-
ing the subway construction shaft occupying the former park site
that was identified as Herald Souare. This received its name from
the newspaper plant above. One-half of this site still contaias
the low original building, the remainder being improved with the
towering Herald Suuare Building.
Broadway is on the left and 6th Avenue on the right. The
former thoroughfare is the vantage point for the photographer in
view 2 and from which he is viewing north-eastward towards the
office building at the N. E. corner of 6th Avenue and W. 35th Street.
View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr
